titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Antony Balcena Papers LSC.0625
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Marisol Ramos-Lum, 2002; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-10-07 15:37:18 -0700.

did.abstract: Antony Galindo Balcena, a Mexican-American, was born in Lompoc, California on April 30, 1954 and died in Los Angeles, California on November 23, 1995. Antony Balcena, (also known as Tony Balcena) was an accomplished dancer, choreographer, and Gay and AIDS activist. He was known for his unique choreographic style and, through his life, he created and performed intimate and controversial performances such as "Dudes" and "Shell of Flesh." This collection documents the life and work of Balcena as a choreographer, dancer, and Gay and AIDS activists.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIO AND AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed audio and audiovisual materials. Audio and audiovisual materials are not currently available for access, unless otherwise noted in a Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed digital materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Antony Balcena papers (Collection Number 625). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Antony Galindo Balcena, a Mexican-American, was born in Lompoc, California on April 30, 1954. Antony Balcena, (also known as Tony Balcena) was an accomplished dancer, choreagrapher and Gay and AIDS activist.

Balcena started taking dance classes at the Riverside Ballet Arts Theater, Riverside, California, in the early 1970s. In 1974 he decided to audition at the Juilliard School of Dancing and was accepted, and later earned his B.F.A. in 1977. He continued his studies and got a M.A. in Dance from UCLA in 1984 and a M.F.A. in Dance from Arizona State University in 1992.

Balcena began his dancing and choreographic career in New York City where he worked on and off Broadway. Balcena dancing style was influenced by the work of Daniel Lewis, who taught him the Limon technique. He worked with Daniel Lewis Dance Repertory Company from 1975 to 1981. Balcena's career covered dancing and bodybuilding. He worked as a professional bodybuilding coach for many years. From 1983 to 1990, he staged and choreographed several bodybuilding competitions (Mr. Olympia, Ms. Olympia, Mr. America and Mr. Universe).

In the 1980s, Balcena returned to Los Angeles where he worked with Sarah Elgart and Co. (1982) as a dancer and eventually became Assistant Director. In 1989 and 1990 he participated in the Los Angeles Dance Kaleidoscope presenting several dancing productions (e.g. "Dudes"). During the 1990s he also choreographed several controversial works about AIDS (e.g. "Shell of Flesh," "AIDS! The Musical"). He also worked as assistant choreographer for films such as "Earth Girls Are Easy" and "Rented Lips."

Balcena received several awards and honors during his career. In 1991, he won a choreographic award from the Nuevo L.A. Chicano Danceworks Festival, and an Award of Merit from the Juilliard School Alumni Association's Los Angeles chapter. He also worked for several years (1983-1993) as an instructor at Loyola Marymount University, Cal State University San Bernardino, and Plaza de La Raza, a Mexican cultural arts center. In 1994, he joined the Dance faculty at Arizona State University. He died on November 23, 1995 of complications resulting from AIDS.

Sources: ASU Insight, October 21, 1991. AIDS! The Musical program brochure, ca. 1991. DUDES, Press release, 1989 OLIO, Sunday, March 28, 1982 Vol. 6. No. 4 AIDS Wall in Protest, http://www.geocities.com/WestHollywood/Heights/3957/ The Estate Project for Artist with AIDS, http://www.artistswithaids.org/artforms/dance/catalogue_index.html Mike and Tony, documentary by Wm. Grimes, 2001.
Different names used by or used for Balcena: Anthony Balcena, Antony Balcena, Tony Balcena, and Anthony Galindo Balcena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection includes videotapes and audiotapes of Antony Balcena's choreographic work from 1974 to 1995. It also consists of publications (novels and newspapers clippings), unpublished materials (theses and typed manuscripts), production materials (programs, flyers, postcard ads), photographs, and slides relating to the life and work of Antony Balcena. A variety of publicity materials (flyers, photographs) to promote his choreographic work supplement this collection.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection was originally arranged in boxes with books, typed manuscripts, photographs and video and audiotapes without any apparent order. The series names were assigned by the processor. The collection was arranged in the following series: 1. Publications (Books, Newspapers clippings) 2. Unpublished Papers (Typed manuscripts, theses) 3. Slides 4. Photographs 5. Videotapes (VHS, BR20 and BR30 tapes) 6. Audiotapes (5" and 7" audiotapes) 7. Production Papers (programs, flyers, postcards ads, publicity photographs)

controlaccess.occupation: Mexican American dancers -- United States -- Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "In Time of Conflict" Note reads: 1971 by Larry Delinger Chored: Antony Balcena Juillard 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Spirit of LA" by Paul Chitens

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Delinger" Note reads: Sitting Delinger Quietus © Larry Delinger 1975-1976. All rights reserved. 7 1/2 ips mono 2 tracks side 1 only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape. Side I has Harry Partch talking about the unique instruments he had created. Side II, titled "Delusion of the Fury," has music composed by Harry Partch and conducted by Danlee Mitchell. The tape included a card with the information about the recording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape. Continuation of the previous audiotape [Box 12 F. 4.] Titled "Delusion of The Fury (A Ritual of Dreams & Delusion)". Side III and Side IV has music from this composion by Harry Patch and conducted by Danlee Mitchell. The tape included a card with the information about the recording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Posing Music for Jessica and Frekas. 000- Part 1 0560 Part 2." Note reads: 15 ips 4 tracks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Chiten and Arboretum/zoo" Note reads: Composed and Performed by Paul Chiten. Choreographed by Antony Balcena. "Radha"--7 1/2 track; "Going" 7 1/2 track; Loyola Marymount University. "Arboretum Zoo;" "Accidental Suicide;" "Oscillae;" "Chiten" 7 1/2 4 Track Tale out. 7.5 ips 1/4 track stereo heads.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 5 in. audiotape titled: "La Malinche." Note reads: 7 1/2 ips 1/4 track stereo Rehearsal only. Good music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Agent Orange Nightmare" Note reads: Choreographer: Antony Balcena. Music: Mark Schafer and "Two Poems" etude Op 42 #3 by Alexander Scriaban/Performed by Vladimir Horowitz. 15 stereo 1/2 track Tail Out.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 7 in. audiotape titled: "Simon" Note reads: 7 1/2 ips 1/2 track mono copy. A letter was included inside the tape. Letter re: suggestion using the music for a choreography by Balcena. It is signed by Dianne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs (black and white and color), negatives and positives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Color prints (4" x 6") of some theatical production with Balcena dancing together with other people. Positives (test sheets) of a selection of the same pictures. The folder also includes negatives of same pictures.
Positives of selected pictures taken by Steven Baratz © 414 Riverdale Dr. Glendale 91204. 818-240-5189. Negatives probably taken by Raymond Garcia 931-8037.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prints without labels and dates that can identify the pictures with the people portrayed in them. Two photos do have the name of the photographers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Production Papers (programs, photos, negatives and other related materials of a theatrical production)

did.unittitle: Dudes, AIDS! The Musical, DART company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Production materials from two different musical production directed and choreographed by Antony Balceda, "Dudes" (1991) and "AIDS! The Musical" (1989). Re: AIDS epidemic. The folder includes brochures, photos, positives (test sheets) and correspondence related to these productions and a dance group called DART Company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prints, flyers and programs for different productions (e.g. "Men," "Dudes," and "Image of Hope").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Programs, flyers and postcards from a variety of choreographies and/or musical plays that Balcena participated, e.g. "The Feast of All Souls;" "Oscillate;" "Annual Spring Dance Concert" at Loyola Marymount (1985, 1990-1991, 1993); "Crossed Lines;" "Brigadoon;" "Mi Hija, Mi Hermano;" "Dudes;" "AIDS! The Musical!." There are several programs from the Sara Elgart & Company where Balcena was a dancer and Assistant Choreographer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Publications include: books, magazines, newspapers (whole or clippings), publicity materials (business cards, advertising postcards, brochures), and Press Releases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advertising postcards for the musical play, "AIDS! The Musical" in 1991. Brochures from the Juilliard School on their dance works in 1977. Balcena business cards for his Hollywood studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letter to the Los Angeles Times editor responding to an article written by Elaine Minamide (also included) re: homophobia. Editorial pages of the Los Angeles Times. Excerpts for Griffin novel titled "Nationwide Butterpump."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Three Press Releases: "Dudes" (1989), "Shell of Flesh/Silence to Say Goodby" (1993), and "Shell of Flesh," as part of the Day Without Art (1990). Newspapers Reviews of different musical plays: "Dance Kaleidoscope: Shell of Flesh" (1989), "Agent Orange Nightmare," and "Shell of Flesh" (1990). Newspapers articles re: Promotion of Day Without Art as part of World AIDS Awareness week (1991, 1993), Balcena going to Arizona State University (ASU) as a graduate student (1991). There are two (2) black and white photographs used as part of the publicity for "Dudes." One was taken in 1994 at ASU by James Corwlin and another one, n.d., was taken by Raymond Garcia. Also, Balcena's resume updated to 1990.
James Cowlin photo included his address and the negative info: Image Enterprises 751 E. Belmont Ave. Phoenix, AZ 85020, 602-944-3266, © 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reviews for the musical plays "Dudes" and "AIDS! The Musical!" Photos and flyers for "Dudes." Program for the musical play "West Side Story: A Charity Parody."
Publicity photo by Raymond Garcia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The folders have several newspapers, whole and clippings, with articles and reviews of Balcena choreographies, dancing roles, boydbuilding jobs, and AIDS activism activities in which he was involved. Articles re: AIDS plays and charities; jobs at Loyola Marymount in Los Angeles and Arizona State University (ASU) at Tempe; acquiring degree at ASU; Daniel Lewis Dance Company. Reviews re: "Shell of Flesh," "Dudes," "AIDS! The Musical," "West Hollywood Story: A Charity Parody," "Gee, I'm really not supposed to be here." Press release re: "Shell of Flesh," "Shard Psalm Triptych." There is also publicity materials such as advertising postcards, and photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 3 newspaper reviews (e.g. "Mi Hija, Mi Hermano;" "Shell of Flesh;" "Shard Psalm Tryptych") and a newspaper interview with Balcena in 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newspapers clipping of news re: ACT-UP and other gays and AIDS activist groups re: protesting Government policies against HIV/AIDS infected people; news of AIDS conferences. ACT-UP and Gay and Lesbian group handbooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 40 slides of various dance performances taken between 1977-1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 5 slides of various dance performances taken in September and October of 1978.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unpublished Materials (thesis, school papers)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A copy of the Anthony (Galindo) Balcena Master of Arts' thesis, from the University of California, Los Angeles, titled "Literature into Dance: The Aesthetics of Yukio Mishima."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A copy of the Antony Balcena Master of Fine Arts's thesis, from Arizona State University, titled "Shard Phalm Triptych."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A school paper titled "Santería: A Kinesthetic Profile" done for the course Music of the Caribbean MHL 598, Dr. Ted Solis, instructor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A short story called "Dead Lung Breathe," inside a longer typed manuscript. First page is numbered 176 and last page is numbered 181.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed manuscript of the novel "Kicks in the Eye" by M. Dylan Griffin. Included a Author's Note that dedicated the novel to Anthony Balcena. One of the main characters in the novel, Gabe, is based on Balcena.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: VHS, BR20, BR30 tapes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 VHS tapes with choreographies by Balcena. One is titled, "Antony Balcena, Movement Director/Choreographer-Sample Reel" (Sample of works such as Fashion and Rock Videos, Bodybuilding and Playboy) and other tape is titled, "HIGHWAYS: Razorblades, Lightbulbs and A Royal Heart" (Sat. 3/6/93).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 2 VHS tapes with choreographies, one by Balcena and another by Sarah Elgart. One is titled, "Tony - AIDS Day 12-1-93- A.S.U." and the other is titled "Pushing Back-- Sara Elgart KCET Excerpt--Judy Garland."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two VHS tapes. A documentary short (2001) by Wm. Grimes titled "Mike and Tony." Re: Balcena's AIDS diagnosis, last days in hospice, his relationship with Mike (Michael) Griffin. And a video of the dance-play "Shard Psalm Tryptych" created and choreographed by Antony Balcena. The folder also included a book by Michael Griffin (1990) titled "Nationwide Butterpump." Excerpts from this book--which is marked throughout with yellow post-it notes--were used in the dance-play "Shard Psalm Tryptych."
The yellow post-it notes marked the pages where text was taken for the play.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two VHS tapes. One is titled: "Westlake School for Girls Westside Story" 3/18/88 Length: 1:59:53 Bill Walter. The other is titled: "Balliano Presents: Dances and Songs from Il Decamerone Di Boccaccio." 6/25/91 /#6722/ 38 minutes.

The video includes these choreographies: "Oscillate" 83-84 UCLA; "Mishima" '84 UCLA; "Arboretum Zoo" '85 LMU; "Radha" '86 LMU; "America is Waiting" (Elgart) LMU '86. The second video is titled: Antony Balcena "Agent Orange Nightmare" (8:03): "Iscukkate":(12:26) 4/11/91 Loyola Marymount U.
UCLA= University of California, Los Angeles. LMU= Loyola Marymount University.
